ygData.msgSnippet: I ve successfully used a patched version of dk.netarkivet.ArcTools.ExtractCDX to generate Wayback-compliant CDX files from an Alexa-style DAT file. My patch is

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I've successfully used a patched version of
dk.netarkivet.ArcTools.ExtractCDX 
to generate Wayback-compliant CDX files from an Alexa-style DAT file. 
My
patch is attached, should it be useful to anyone.
 
Regards,
Andy Boyko    aboy@...
Library of Congress - Office of Strategic Initiatives


>>> lc@... 5/3/2004 9:38:05 AM >>>

On Wed, 2004-04-07 at 12:57, kaisa_kaunonen wrote:
> Hi, 
> 
> I collected a nice test archive of about 100000 docs with 
> heritrix 0.6.0
> I think it went well (I didn't yet try out very baaad web sites;)
>  
> Now I try to index the archive with nwatoolset. 
> At this point it seems that cdx files are needed.
> How do I generate them? 

To get away from the Alexa tools, which can be quite difficult to
compile, we have developed some Java tools that are available at
www.netarchive.dk.  They can make (unsorted) cdx files from
(uncompressed) arc files[1], do binary searches and get entries out of
arc files, and write new arc files.  They're not optimized for huge
collections like the Alexa tools are, for instance can't handle
multi-file cdx files yet, but we use them internally with success. 
They're all under GPL, and improvements are welcome.

-Lars

[1] Actually, they do support compressed arc files, except they can't
figure out the length of the compressed entry, so they can't scan
through them.  There's ways to do that, but I at least prefer to just
not compress the files.
